comments:
I received the following error in my console when creating a Web project in last week's I-build. No idea if it has caused any real problems yet - Web facet seems to be installed correctly although there is an error on web.xml: "Referenced file contains errors (http://www.ibm.com/webservices/xsd/j2ee_web_services_client_1_1.xsd)"

Caused by: org.xml.sax.SAXParseException: Element type "QueryString.keys.length" must be followed by either attribute specifications, ">" or "/>".
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.DOMParser.parse(DOMParser.java:264)
	at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.jaxp.DocumentBuilderImpl.parse(DocumentBuilderImpl.java:292)
	at org.eclipse.xsd.util.XSDResourceImpl.getDocument(XSDResourceImpl.java:339)
	... 80 more

See bug 152355 for the cause.

The model is trying to resolve the schemas.  It comes to the point where it tries to parse the missing schema (location http://www.ibm.com/webservices/xsd/j2ee_web_services_client_1_1.xsd which is redirected to some other web page, and it tries to parse this.)

So the parser throws a SAXException.  The XSD model then logs this problem using its logger, and hence, you see the trace in the log file.

Another issue here relates to bug 117232.  From the stack trace it looks like we're attempting to load a grammar inorder to create a nice empty tag.  

org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.document.ElementImpl.preferEmptyTag(ElementImpl.java:964)
org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.document.XMLModelUpdater.replaceChild(XMLModelUpdater.java:1470)

IMHO, the grammar model should only get loaded when the XML is being edited.  In cases where the DOM model is being used for the purposes of creating an EMF model I think we'd want to avoid the creation of grammar models at the very least for performance related reasons.

traces.message: Element type "QueryString.keys.length" must be followed by either attribute specifications, ">" or "/>".

causedBy.message: Element type "QueryString.keys.length" must be followed by either attribute specifications, ">" or "/>".
